description:
Cebus imitator, commonly known as the white-fronted capuchin or Panamanian white-faced capuchin, is a species of New World monkey found in parts of Central America. It is a member of the genus Cebus, which includes various species of capuchin monkeys.

The Cebus imitator is a medium-sized primate with a distinctive white or cream-colored face, and a dark brown or black body. They are highly intelligent and known for their adaptability, using a variety of foraging techniques and tools to obtain food. These monkeys are primarily arboreal, living and moving through the forest canopy.

Cebus imitator is considered a social species, living in groups ranging from a few individuals to over 30 members. They communicate through a range of vocalizations and visual cues, and exhibit complex social behaviors, including cooperation, conflict resolution, and even tool-use.

The species is found in parts of Panama, Costa Rica, and possibly western Colombia, inhabiting various types of tropical forests. They play an important role in their ecosystem as seed dispersers and contribute to the overall biodiversity of the region.

Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect Cebus imitator, as their populations have been impacted by habitat loss and fragmentation due to human activities such as deforestation and urbanization.
